comments.body:
Fixed the grammar in the second paragraph.

The old paragraph reads:

> For more advanced use cases, subclassing `keras.layers.Layer` is preferred. One reason for this is that when saving a Model, `Lambda` layers are saved by serializing the Python bytecode, whereas subclassed Layers are saved via overriding their `get_config` method and are thus more portable. Models that rely on subclassed Layers are also often easier to visualize and reason about.
Sorry I didn't notice this earlier. The last line is not grammatically correct and is confusing. Overall, I still feel that the old paragraph reads better than this one.
You're right. I did put the last part back in.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +656,660 @@  for subclassing `tf.keras.layers.Layer`. 
  
  The main reason to subclass `tf.keras.layers.Layer` instead of using a 
  `Lambda` layer is saving and inspecting a Model. `Lambda` layers 
  are saved by serializing the Python bytecode, whereas subclassed
